President Trump has shown Black America once again that we are not his priority. The @TheBlackCaucus vehemently opposes this budget and will fight for policies and programs that improve the lives of hard working Americans by closing the wealth gap, instead of increasing it.

While Americans will lose out on critical economic, social, and healthcare support, his budget depends on unrealistic economic predictions to make ends meet. So, what can we be sure of? Trump‚Äôs budget will lead to higher deficits, a weaker economy, and a widening wealth gap.

Other disastrous cuts include a 9% decrease to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention in the middle of a global Coronavirus outbreak, leaving low income communities in America the most vulnerable.

In addition to significantly slashing the budget for these programs, President Trump intends to make access to these programs harder, which will disproportionately affect the minority communities who access these programs.

The proposed budget would cut healthcare spending, including Medicare, Medicaid, and the Children‚Äôs Health Insurance Program, by $844 billion. His budget would also cut SNAP (formerly known as food stamps) by $182 billion, and cut social security disability benefits by $70 bn.
By targeting the social safety net and healthcare, he has singled out programs designed to provide support for American families in the greatest need.

Our bill is comprehensive, because this crisis demands it. And it's achievable, because the people are behind us.
Congress must take up this legislation now. #BreakFreeFromPlastic http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EQg3i4_WoAAUFJ2.jpg

How does the bill work?
1. We phase out single-use items that can‚Äôt be recycled. 
 
2. We shift responsibility for managing waste to the producers, so they'll make more sustainable products.
 
3. We prioritize communities that bear the worst cost of plastic pollution.

Not only is it expensive‚Äî most of our plastic waste isn't getting recycled anyway. The vast majority ends up in landfills, incinerators, or in our oceans and gutters. And meanwhile, the endless production of plastic is now a leading contributor to greenhouse gas emissions.

Big corporations are making more and more single-use plastics and unnecessary packaging, fooling us into thinking that plastic is convenient, widely recyclable, and easily and cheaply disposed of. But that's just not true.

So what can we do?
-We can ‚Äì and must ‚Äì pass bold legislation to end the pollution and #BreakFreeFromPlastic. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EQg3iWNX0AAZIhH.jpg

How does plastic pollution hurt us?
-It's polluting rivers, lakes, oceans and landscapes,
-accelerating climate change,
-infiltrating our bodies and killing wildlife,
-breaking local government budgets since they can't afford to recycle anymore.

Where is plastic pollution?
-in our communities
-in our air
-in our water
-in our food
-in our bodies

In short: it‚Äôs everywhere, and it doesn‚Äôt biodegrade.

The plastic pollution crisis is past the tipping point. It threatens our health, our economy, and our planet.

As our friend Frank Stephens would say, Cole‚Äôs life is worth living. Today, he‚Äôs almost 13 years old. He's smart & loves sports. He‚Äôs a great big brother to our daughters Grace & Brynn. All five of us just skied down Mt. Spokane this weekend. It was a joy for the entire family.

But Cole‚Äôs life couldn‚Äôt be further from what we were told. He‚Äôs opened our eyes to the dignity and potential of every life. He‚Äôs reminded me that just because challenges in life are hard, it doesn‚Äôt mean they aren‚Äôt valuable.

Doctors gave us a long list of challenges and complications. We were told don‚Äôt expect much. In that moment, I could see how the fear of the unknown could make us question everything. 

Could we give Cole everything that life had to offer? Could we handle this?

I think back to the uncertainty, the fear. Even when I was pregnant it was scary, especially the first time! My oldest Cole was born with Down syndrome. It wasn‚Äôt what Brian or I hoped for or dreamed.

That changed in my first term when I met Brian. We got married and became pregnant shortly after. Three kids later, I can testify today that becoming a mom has been the best thing to have happened in my life. The absolute best thing.

Every woman‚Äôs journey to motherhood is different. Something that unites us though is the uncertainty and fear of the unknown.

For me, I was 35 and single when I was elected to Congress. I wasn‚Äôt sure about having kids. Was I a baby person? Would it ever happen for me?
